results.name: David Caesar
results.biography:
David Caesar (born 1963) is an Australian television and film director and writer. He grew up in Turlinjah on the south coast of NSW and attended school in nearby Moruya where he was school captain in his senior year.
Caesar graduated from the Australian Film Television and Radio School in 1987. He won an AWGIE and best director at Shanghai Film Festival for his film MULLET.  He won a Queensland Premiers Literary award for the screenplay for PRIME MOVER in 2008.

results.name: Peter Tscherkassky

roles_in_work.title: [Musterrolle: a compilation of short films by Peter Tscherkassky]
[Musterrolle: a compilation of short films by Peter Tscherkassky]
Motion picture (La Sortie des Ouvriers de l'Usine Lumiere a Lyon)

results.biography:
Peter Tscherkassky
- born in 1958 in Vienna. From 1979 to 1984 he lived in Berlin and studied philosophy. He is a filmmaker since 1979 and received the National Award to the Art of Film in 1989 and 1995. He teaches filmmaking at the Universities of Applied Arts in Wien and Linz. Tscherkassky is a founding member of Sixpack Film. He organised several international avant-garde film festivals in Vienna. He has published extensively and given lectures on the history and theory of avant-garde film.
F i l m o g r a p h y : (selection) 1982: Erotique; 1983: Freeze Frame; 1984: Motion Picture (La Sortie des Ouvriers de l'Usine Lumiere a Lyon); 1985: Manufraktur; 1986: kelimba; 1987/89: tabula rasa; 1987: Shot-Countershot; 1992: Parallel Space: Inter-View; 1996: Happy End; 1998: L'Arrivee; 1999: Outer Space.

Biography from Six Pack Films.

results.name: Michael Buckley

roles_in_work.title: The Greatest Art Movement: Transporting Art: the Story of Melbourne's Art Trams
Two songs by Dougie Young. Dread beat and blood

results.biography: Michael Buckley is an award winning experimental and documentary filmmaker and new media artist. He has a strong commitment to working as an independent and community artist and activist. Michael is a senior lecturer in multimedia at Victoria university in Melbourne. In 2002 he was awarded a fellowship in new media by the new media arts board of the Australia council in recognition of his creative contribution to this field.

results.name: Stephen Jones

roles_in_work.title: Peter Combe's Christmas under the stars
The Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras Parade

results.biography:
Stephen Jones was born in Sydney in 1951 He first became interested in video in 1973 after meeting members of Bush Video. One of Stephen's first works in 1975 was made with an audio synthesiser being fed into an oscilliscope that traced and layered the patterns of the sounds. He built his first `real' video synthesiser in 1979. In 1982 he established the highly influential post-production facility Heuristic Video and began his ten-year association as videomaker for the music group Severed Heads.

In providing technical support for numerous performance and video artists (including Nam June Paik and Charlotte Moorman) he has developed a range of techniques using the Fairlight CVI, the conjure computer graphics system and the Amiga computer.

Jones is particularly interested in organisation and self-regulating systems along with developing a visual language to communicate complex ideas.For the past twenty-five years Jones has been copnducting research into the relationship between neuroscience and the nature of consciousness, culminating in The Brain Project, a web site which has been in development since 1996.

Jones is the recipient of an Australia Council Fellowship, through the New Media Arts Fund. He now works as a consultant electronic engineer and builder of video studios.

References:
Dead Eyes Opened , 1982-85, colour, sound, ? min
Hot with Fleas , 1986-87, colour, sound, ? min
The Brain Project , 1996, web site
Bibliography:
Mazurek, Amy An Interview with Stephen Jones and Tom Ellard, March 1994
Videos by Severed Heads http://www.sevcom.com/video.htm

results.name: Peter Hennessey

roles_in_work.title: My Woomera Project (What do you fear?)

results.biography:
Peter Hennessey is an artist whose work encompasses sculpture, video and interactive media.  In 1994, with artist Patricia Piccinini, he initiated The Basement Project, an artist-run-space in Melbourne that ran until 1997.  Hennessey graduated in Architecture from RMIT in 1995 and with Piccinini, founded Drome.  Drome is a studio dedicated to providing a context and support for artists to make contemporary art and a producer of collaborative projects with artists and arts organisations.

Hennessey's exhibitions include: Repercussions, Greenaway Art Gallery, Adelaide, as part of the Adelaide Festival (2004); and Closer, a collaboration with the dance company Chunky Move, which was shown at the Perth Festival (2004), ACMI (2003), and the Performance Space, Sydney (2003).  In 2002 his work was included in Akhihabara TV in Tokyo.  LumpCD, a Drome project, was completed in 1999 and has been exhibited in galleries and festivals in the Netherlands, Japan and Australia.

Taken from the PROOF exhibition 2004.

results.name: Ray Harryhausen
results.biography:
Raymond Frederick Harryhausen (June 29, 1920 – May 7, 2013) was an American-British animator and special effects creator who created a form of stop motion model animation known as "Dynamation". His works include the animation for Mighty Joe Young (1949) with his mentor Willis H. O'Brien (for which the latter won the Academy Award for Best Visual Effects); his first color film, The 7th Voyage of Sinbad (1958); and Jason and the Argonauts (1963), which featured a sword fight with seven skeleton warriors. His last film was Clash of the Titans (1981), after which he retired.
In 1960, Harryhausen moved to the United Kingdom and became a dual American-British citizen. He lived in London until his death in 2013. During his life, his innovative style of special effects in films inspired numerous filmmakers. In November 2016 the BFI compiled a list of those present-day filmmakers who claim to have been inspired by Harryhausen, including Steven Spielberg, Peter Jackson, Joe Dante, Tim Burton, Nick Park, James Cameron, and Guillermo del Toro. Others influenced by him include George Lucas, John Lasseter, John Landis, Henry Selick, J. J. Abrams, and Wes Anderson.
